												Star Wars Battlefront II is one of my favorite shooters I have played in my life. It trumps Call of Duty, and even Battlefield, in my opinion. It will evoke the classic feeling of Star Wars inside of you, whether you're a new fan or an old one. The game is hilariously unbalanced and the AI is very broken at times, but the childlike wonder of being a jedi or being a stormtrooper almost always shields that from my sight. The space dogfights are awesome once you get the hang of them as well, and it's also very fun to infiltrate enemy ships and blow them up from the inside.All in all, if I had to give it a rating I'd give this game a 9/10. It's definitely worth it's small pricetag.TO ANYONE WHO CAN NOT CONTACT KEY SERVER - I suggest opening a Steam support ticket. They should be able to help.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
  “When 900 years old, you reach… Look as good, you will not.” -Master YodaStar Wars Battlefront II, beginning as a mod for the acclaimed Battlefield series and later attaining its own featured release, has been, is, and always will be one of my favorite games. While writing this review, I was at a loss for words in regards to the overabundance of joy that this game has brought me through the years, and I can proudly say that I own every variance of this game, including the PC, Playstation 2, and Xbox versions. Overall, I have spent more time playing this game than any other game in my library, which includes a massive set of classics such as the Jak & Daxter series, 007 Goldeneye, the Sonic the Hedgehog collection, and even the Pokemon franchise, which I have solely worked over hundreds of hours of play! I apologize that this review may not be as professional, and will be more of a fan’s remembrance to this awesome game. Before I begin, I would like to give a special thanks to some good friends-one being Lime Dorito-that put up with pre-reading this review, as well as my brother, Matthew, for playing countless hours of this game with me on the other ports.Here are some things that I love about Star Wars Battlefront II:Gameplay - Star Wars Battlefront II is a war game, plain and simple. There are about six classes to choose from in each of the respective four armies, and playable Heroes such as Luke Skywalker and Boba Fett are available. This title also allows players to engage in vehicular combat, even hosting maps for dogfights in space against two rivalling fleets. Described earlier, there are several game modes similar to that of the Battlefield games, though Battlefront II has a unique game mode known as Assault, where Heroes from both the Good and Evil spectrums of the Star Wars films battle against each other. Overall, the game balances very well between aerial and ground combat, and evolves into a truly unique experience over multiplayer; unfortunately, the company that originally hosted the dedicated servers for Battlefront II, GameSpy is no longer operational, so other means of multiplayer are required on the PC port.Game Modes - In Campaign Mode, you mirror the Star Wars trilogy while playing as this group of soldiers as they influence the structure of the story that fans of only the movies know and love; this concept is similar to Star Wars Dark Forces in which the character Kyle Katarn is the one who was said to steal the Death Star plans for the Rebellion. Unlike the other Star Wars games such as Bounty Hunter and Dark Forces, Battlefront II maintains a focus on a specific group of Stormtroopers-rather than a single individual-infamously known by fans of the extended universe as the 501st, or Vader’s Fist. The Campaign introduces gameplay unique to the rest of the game in that it is objective-based, contrary to the usual skirmishes. For example, instead of a player dropping into a battlefield without an pretense as to what to do and why they’re fighting, the player is briefed on the purpose of the mission beforehand to perform a specific task such as protecting a Command Post for a given amount of time, or to locate a driver for a downed AT-AT that requires services.  ///  Galactic Conquest Mode is a change of pace, as players strategically maneuver battleships across a large map in an attempt to overtake all territories. This game mode features out-of-battle unit purchasing as well as upgrades that allow the player to determine how they want to progress in an all-out war  against a rivaling army; the opposing force depends on which era of the Star Wars universe you are in, and pits either the CIS against Clone Troopers or the Empire versus the Rebellion.  ///  Don’t want to worry about progressing through the story in Campaign Mode or strategically planning your way through Galactic Conquest? Give Instant Action Mode a go! Skirmish is exactly what it sounds like: you pick the game mode you want to play-between Conquest, Hunt, 1- and 2-Flag CTF, Space Assault, Assault, and Space 1-Flag CTF-and go from there. There are various settings for each, as well as playable Jedi/Heroes.Class System - Like Battlefield, this title has multiple unique classes that operate differently. Every class has their own unique appearance, primary and secondary weapons, statistics, and secondary equipment. For example, the Engineer class is much quicker due to his primary weapon being a shotgun. This class has a low rate of fire and a quick land speed, and is meant to splice into or repair vehicles with their Fusioncutters; it is played like a support class in most instances, but can easily clear singular enemies without a problem. The Engineer is also equipped with Detpacks-which are detonated remotely-and health and ammo dispensers.TL:DR - I had planned to write about weapon similarities between this game and the movies, as well as other topics, but if I had to talk about everything that is good about this game I would be typing for days. As you can tell from the above quote and through each of the screenshots, the Battlefront series does not look as polished in comparison to modern titles. However, this is just one of those games that stands the test of time with its amazing feel and fanatical impression. If you are a Star Wars fan, this title should not be passed up; if you are a Star Wars Battlefront fan, this installment to the series will not be forgotten. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

Posted: December 13, 2014
												It is easy to rip on the Star Wars prequels. You can picket and cry foul that Lucas betrayed your childhood and that he turned a once revolutionary film series into a sameless Disney style toy template (Oh the irony). However, you should consider all the good it has brought as well. Cool music from John Williams, double lightsabers, awesome new spacecraft and Video Games.Amongst the heaps of shovelware Lucasarts published during the prequel frenzy there were a bunch of amazing gems. Like Episode One Racer, Knights of the Old Republic, Battle for Naboo, Galactic Battlegrounds and eventually: Battlefront. Based off the Battlefield: 1942 concept, Battlefront allowed players to experience the battles of both the prequels and originals from the perspective of the ordinary stormtrooper or battledroid. It was amazing, but was not enough.Enter Battlefront 2, the bigger, better and more amazing version of an already amazing game. Fear the day when stormtroopers suddenly learn how to shoot, because that is when you're really playing this game. In general, the game is split in two different modes: Single and Mulitplayer. In singleplayer you play the tour of duty of the 501st Legion of the clone army, who after defeating the seperatist droid army become the elite troopers under the command of Darth Vader. The whole campaign is a short sequence with random objectives, but the whole is narrated by Temuera Morrison, the actor for Jango Fett and every Clone trooper ever. It adds some legitimacy to the whole romp. The other major single player mode is Galactic Conquest. It is a large scale turn based tactics game where you try to manouver your fleet with troops around the galaxy and subjugate (or liberate, if you're into that sort of thing; you tree sniffing hippie). You can employ bonusses, granted to you by owning certain planets.On the other hand of the spectum is multiplayer; and this is the reason why we're here. Allowing 64 peeps to take to the field at the same time...that's real warfare. This game was at the frontline of modern FPS development. You'll see many mainstays of modern shooters make their debut here, such as endurance rewards, killstreak rewards and other unlockable perks. Most destructive of the lot are the Jedi units. The ultimate streak reward gives you access one of the saga's heroes and elevates your lowly soldier rank to harbinger of death with a lightsaber. The sheer terror, characters like Darth Maul and Mace Windu inspire is amazing as they cut through swathes of troops. The real selling point though are the maps. The maps are open and wide to accomodate the massive amount of players. However, each map has a lot of secret passages and corridors that allow for exploration and experimentation. On top of that, the level of detail is amazing. Intricate care was taken to make all the maps look like they came right off the movie screen. You can run around the death star, from the hangar with the falcon, into the prison block, jump into the grabage shute, fight through the barracs, blow up the main laser, pace past the tractor beam generator, kick over the conference table where Vader expressed his opinion about a lack of faith and finally back to the hangar, all in one level.Along side are the space battle stages. These battles are big, point based levels where you take to the stars in fighters, bombers and boarding craft. You either earn points by shooting down other fighters in dogfights or bomb their capital ships to bits, or you board them and start sabotaging their internal systems. It's a sweet change of pace, although it can be hassle to fly without a gamepad. It's therefore a shame the game's description on the Steam store reads that all online functionality in dead as of this year's May. Which is pure bantha poodoo. You still get around with some trickery. Even better, at this pricepoint, you might just better off telling all your friends to just buy it and bring their laptop over (it's old enough to run on any potato at this point), and just host a massive LAN party to restore balance to Force once and for all.

NOTE 1: The game is OLD, being released back in 2005 so most likely than not you will encounter compatibility issues. I feel the need to point this out since it is not the game's fault that its 9 years old. There are 3 possible solutions to this:1. Right Click Battlefront 2 on Steam > Properties > Local Files > Browse Local Files, this will open the Battlefront 2 folder, Open GameData > Right click 'Battlefront II.exe' > Properties > Compatibility > Check 'Run this program in Compatibility for: Windows XP SP2.2. Plug in a microphone to your microphone jack, people on the forums report that this actually (usually) work.3. 


YouTube™ Video: How to fix the star wars battlefront 2 crash!!! 

			Views: 81,430		

			this will fix the crash and allow sound aswell. Some other ways to fix the crash is by deleting the sound, but i found a way to do it by saving the sound :D.		

 (Follow the instructions on this video, this worked for me).NOTE 2: The game supports 1080p resolution. Only the main menu, loading screens and pre-rendered cinematic are low resolution. The game itself, once you get it running, runs at a pristine 1080p, 60fps.INTRODUCTION:Star Wars: Battefront 2 is a first / third-person shooter game by LucasArts involving Star Wars' (duh) different histories ranging from the start of the Clone Wars towards Empire Strikes Back. It features soldier classes, hero characters, galactic conquest and a particularly fun space battle.The campaign follows the rough history of the 501st Clone/Stormtrooper Legion, Darth Vader's personal bodyguards and elite fighting force. As already stated, this will involve the events of Episode II: Clone Wars, up until Episode V: Empire Strikes back.PROS:+ Graphics aged well: - The old Pandemic Zero Engine is showing it's age but is not about to go down without a fight. Animation Quality is fluid, character models are well made, texture quality are very good for its time.+ Relatively Strong Campaign: - Short but satisfying is what I would describe the campaign. Voiced by none other than Temuera Morrison (Jango Fett), it delivers the exploits of the 501st Legion in a very informative and fun experience. Unfortunately the maps are only multilayer maps with given objectives.+ Space Battle: - Nothing beats the excitement of piloting different kinds of fighters and bombers to attack key points on the enemy battleship or engage in open space dogfights. If that’s not your thing, then land your fighter (or a transport ship) in the enemy Hanger area and start wreaking havoc with the ship's internal systems. Or just steal an enemy fighter.CONS:- AI is too easy: - Way to easy once you get a hang of it even when fighting 'Elite' difficulty AI.- Campaign is too short: - Given that I already played it back in the day, it took me at least 4-5 hours to finish the story mode.- Hilariously Imbalanced in some places: - Not game-breaking by any stretch, but the game does lack the rock, paper, scissors element that usually balances out multiplayer games. Some of the maps tend to favor one particular faction than the other.- AI is annoyingly dumb: - Especially in space battles. I get that you're a Stormtrooper and can't shoot to save your life, but standing around the hanger just staring at the wall instead of boarding a fighter and helping me fend off the millions of rebel fighters bearing down on us is a whole new level of incompetence.CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME and lots of FUN. The PROS definitely outweigh the CONS and that it provides a cure for that need for a casual fast paced action game. The single player experience is enough to keep you satisfied if you lack the online capabilities or when GameSpy inevitably shuts down.We can just hope that EA handles the franchise with care as the sequel for this game is already way overdue.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												A synthesized battle droid voice comes over into your ears.Enemy units detected inside the command craft.Seconds later, the CIS battlecruiser bursts into chunks, wisps of fire dying in the vacuum of space as sunlight crests the nearby Republic planet.You chuckle and a "Victory" readout appears before you.And that's just a moment in Battlefront 2.- - -While Star Wars Battlefront 2 is, y'know, ancient at this point, it is still a beauty in gaming and the serious nostalgia trip for so many of us. I, being a late-comer to gaming and Battlefront 2 being one of the earlier console games I played (along with GUN and I believe Flatout), can quickly say that this game is gorgeous and sold the industry to me.It's massive, it's immersive, it's quick-to-play, and it's Star Wars! Who doesn't like Star Wars? Well, plenty of people, but... hey, you can't dislike the adorable Stormtroopers.You've got all the stuff other shooting games do. Guns, people to shoot guns, and some extra things like vehicles. Then there's the space battles, which make an entirely different challenge and one of the most glorious flying experiences in gaming, and then you've got the tactical 'Conquest' part where you put around a giant fleet of spacecraft for your favorite faction in the Star Wars movies.Rebels, Empire/Republic, CIS: You can play as any of them, which is great fun. Each have their own soldiers and classes, allowing different experiences for every team. It's especially cool to roll around as a droideka, then unfurl and be destroyed by a Jedi. At least you're the envy of your friends.The battles themselves are manic and titanic. Hoth a devoid planet? Not when you're in the middle of a 100+ person skirmish between Rebels and Imperials. AT-AT action is amazing, until you're taken down by some jerk in a cheap snowspeeder. Maybe it was SKYWALKER?No.There's also that option to play as a Jedi or Sith or melodramatic bounty hunter popping up every now-and-then, but they're lame and die too quickly. I don't suggest them. Well, MBH is alright, but who wants to get eaten by a sandpit monster?There's the few issues, like absurdly dumb AI and logical errors (downwards gravity in space?), but they're far and few compared to the joy this game brings.I couldn't recommend this enough. And it's only 10 bucks USD!

												Star Wars Battlefront II (Soon to likely be called Star Wars Battlefront II: The Good One) is a classic Star Wars game many fans have fond memories of.But does it hold up?...Well, duh, why would most of the reviews be positive?The gameplay is as smooth as Lando, and tight like a chain around Jabba's neckIt may look it's aged as well as Yoda, but that's to be expected with a game that is over 10 years old (which in game development time may be a couple hundred years).The music is what you would expect, it's Star Wars.The story... Posted: December 8, 2015
												I think the most efficient way to review this would be a non (slightly) biased comparison of this Battlefront (Lucas Arts / L.A) with EA's new Battlefront.-GAMEPLAYL.A take the lead with this one. Pretty easily to be honest. Much more game modes, maps, factions etc.. 1-0, to L.A.-GRAPHICSWhat do you expect. L.A's is 10 years old. 10 YEARS OLD. 1-1.-REPLAYABILITYWhile EA's multiplayer leveling system offer some replayability, L.A's wider range, and much larger density, of content give L.A the point. Also, and i will refer to this quite a bit, not everyone likes multiplayer. 2-1 to L.A.-SINGLEPLAYEREA doesn't really know how to create a good singleplayer. At all. In fact, it seems they've given up on the idea altogether. Rest in peace EA - post Battlefield 2 / Bad Company. The lack of singleplayer is a negative point for EA, and L.A's extremely well done singleplayer, including a campaign, critically acclaimed Galactic conquest, and instant action give L.A a well-deserved point. 3-0-MULTIPLAYEREA get a point by default, as L.A's multiplayer was decommisioned a while back. While i deducted a point from EA for not having a singleplayer, i will not do so with L.A for the lack of multiplayer as, a) there was once upon a time, and b) the expansive singleplayer more than makes up for it. There are dozens of singleplayer only games and L.A's Battlefront is one of the best. 3-1 to L.A.-MOD SUPPORTTime has been of L.A's side, with multitudes of mods being released, a lot of them can be considered as unofficial expansions. A conversion pack has been developed, adding the favourite instant action maps from L.A's 1st Battlefront. Who doesn't like free additional content. 4-1 to L.A.-PRICEL.A's Battlefront is $15 on steam (I got my copy on special for $5). Fair enough for an old game. EA's is around $80. L.A's has a LOT more content, + mods such as the conversion pack. 1/5 of the price for (in my opinion) a much better game. 5-1.-ACCESSABILITYI can run L.A's Battlefront with 128 bots, maxed settings, easily over 60 fps, on my laptop. While L.A's Battlefront is only available on steam, Xbox + Xbox 360, and PS2, EA's is only available on the newer platforms (so tough luck for fellow laptop users). Also, for console users, EA's is multiplayer only (effectively) so hooray for online costs. Close battle, but point to L.A. 6-1.OVERRALLIf this was a football match, L.A's Battlefront would be Barcelona, and EA's would be Norwich. EA has yet again disappointed with its money-mongering and lack of singleplayer ability. I'm pretty sure EA have just produced the 1st clickbait-like game, not sure why they didn't call it Battlefield: Star Wars and save the royalty costs. Congrats to L.A's Battlefront for beating a game 10 years newer,

												Want a game that's stupid fun AND an accurate representation of what large scale battles in the Star Wars universe are like? Well, this is your game.Pros:-Over a hundred troops per side!-Amazing, immersive space battles!-Massive, large scale land battles!-A class-based system requiring you to unlock better classes through points earned.-The ability to play as a Jedi (a feature the first game lacked, even though you ended up having to fight them).-A completely revamped "Galactic Conquest" mode.-A story demonstrating the fall of the 501st Legion, the army Anikin used to betray the Jedi, and the rise of the Empire.-Only $10!Cons:-Stormtrooper-esque AI-Balancing issues (Mainly with Super Battle Droids. Why were these guys changed from unlockable troops to footsoldiers? They start off with a rocket launcher... as an off-hand weapon!).-An annoying lack of space stages; only 6 in total.-The company in charge of running the online servers went out of business, so no online play.In my opinion, the pros absolutely outweight the cons. Plus, keep in mind I haven't tried playing at higher difficulties than "Normal" yet, so I don't know if their AI gets better. All and all, though, it is a fun game and I absolutely recommend it to any fan of the Star Wars franchise.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Star Wars: Battlefront II is a 2005 first- and third-person shooter video game based on the Star Wars film franchise. Developed by Pandemic Studios and published by LucasArts it is a sequel to 2004's Star Wars: Battlefront and the second game in the Battlefront series.The game features new vehicles, characters, game mechanics, maps, and missions compared to the original Battlefront. Unlike its predecessor, Battlefront II features a more narrative-based campaign, retelling portions of the Star Wars story from the point of view of a veteran Imperial stormtrooper, reminiscing about his tour of duty in service of both the Galactic Republic and as part of the Galactic Empire. Gameplay additions over Battlefront include the use of Jedi, additional game modes such as hero assault, and objective-based space battles. The general objective in most missions is to eliminate the enemy faction. Like Star Wars Battlefront, the game is split into two eras, the Clone Wars and the Galactic Civil War. You have the ability to choose between six classes during gameplay. Four class types are common to all factions; infantry, heavy weapon, sniper and engineer. In addition to the four standard classes, each faction has two unique classes which unlock by scoring a predetermined number of points.  For the Rebellion faction, the Bothan Spy and the Wookiee; for the Empire, The Officer and The Dark Trooper; for the Republic, the Commander and the Jet Trooper; and for the CIS, the Magnaguard and the Droideka.Battlefront II contains only one campaign, called Rise of the Empire. This set of missions is presented as the narration of a veteran of the 501st Legion, known as Vader's Fist, beginning with an attack on the planet Mygeeto during the Clone Wars and ending with the assault on Hoth as depicted in The Empire Strikes Back. There are a total of 18 missions, four of which are optional space missions.Overall I would give STAR WARS Battlefront II a score of 8/10, it is a fun and entertaining game that doesn't have very much problems and the instant action with the bots is just awesome. Having played DICE's new STAR WARS Battlefront, I decided to go back and try the originals and I realized how much better they were, no customization and ranks, just pure fun. So if you're looking for a fun STAR WARS game I would recommend this as it just beats any other!.

												This is the best Star Wars game of all time and I will tell you why.First, since the 7th movie was coming out soon, I decided to start playing this game again and I just beat the campaign and played a bunch of instant action. I also played some multiplayer with GameRanger. I now think I can wright a review for this game.We will start with the pros and consPros:-Surprisingly fun campaign: you play as the 501st clone division and soon become Vader's Fist. You play in a bunch of the iconic battles from the original series and the prequels.-All four armies: in this game you get to play as either the clones vs. the separatists (Robots) or the Rebels vs. the Empire-A lot of Heroes: you get to play as Luke Skywalker, Boba Fett, Darth Vader, etc... There is almost a different hero for a different map.-Fluent controls: the controls in this game are smooth and it feels good when you shoot rebel scum in the face with your E-11.-Space battles: The fact that this game had space battles where you can land on the other team’s ship and destroy it from the inside was ahead of its time and no other games captures space battles like this one. There are also different ships for different occasions like there is an x-wing for destroying regular enemies and y--wings to bomb their cruiser.-A lot of maps: There is a bunch of maps in this game like Endor, Hoth, Geonosis, and much more.-64 player battles: This is self explanatory-Modable: If you pair this game with mods you can have an even better time with this game and if add all the user made maps with the ones in this game, there are over 800 maps for this game!!!Cons:-Aging: This game is 10 years old and there aren't too many people playing this game on Game Ranger. The graphics are out of date and sadly Pandemic studios went out of business in 2009.-Unstable: This ties in with the last con. The game has plenty of bugs and crapy hit boxes that will no longer be fixed (varies on each map [user created or not]). The overall function of the game also varies depending on your computer. It will still most likely function properly.That's about all the consOverall:Star Wars Battlefront 2 is one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made and in my opinion, It is one of the greatest games ever made.This game gets a 9/10. I highly recommend this game to any shooter fan and every Star Wars fan alike.I hope you found this review helpful. Posted: February 9
												Story: We all know the story.... what's most important is the gameplay and that they don't bomb the plot. Here you get a pretty bare bones campaign that follows the 501st. There's almost a great simplicity to this stuff. First of all I love that they didn't force this campaign into a corridor shooter. They keep the levels pretty free-roam and similar to the instant action (just with objectives). This probably made development easier, but it works, unlike modern multiplayer shooters where the campaign feels tacked on. The 501st is a great choice of perspective but not much is done with it. There is the potential for a lot of conflict and a kind of clone soul-searching. After watching the Clone Wars animated series, I really saw what could've been done with exploring the humanity of clones and their connection to the jedi. But then again this isn't really important to this game or what it's remember for.Gameplay: This game is straight forward action, not too fast, not too slow. This game is pretty easy to jump into. Its controls are intuitive and the third person camera makes it easy to understand and move around your environment. Starting out, you feel like an above-average soldier, you stick to your comrades, use similar weapons, and take cp's together. As you begin to master the combat, you begin to unlock weapon upgrades and once these are permanently unlocked you become a god on the battlefield. The gameplay is pretty shallow at this point and you'll find yourself hardly dying while taking every cp. I wish the game was a bit harder, but then again its not really why you play the game. You are rewarded often with the chance to play as a hero. Overall these moments are fun and rushed. The controls again are basic compared to something like jedi knight, but the heroes are really just there as a killing spree bonus. What adds depth to the game is the variety of maps and the ways to play the maps. When you develop some favorites you find there are a multitude of ways to win a game. Now probably the best part of the game and where it shines the most is when playing against friends. Playing against friends with bots creates such a fun dynamic. The moments where you run into your friend among a horde of bots and have to fight your way to each other then face-off in a tense duel is some serious fun! The unbalanced nature of different factions on different maps adds a realistic sense where someone's the underdog and if they win its quite embarrassing for the other player. I loved this aspect of the game also because it overshadowed the dumb AI which can reveal itself to be quite predictable after some time.Game Modes: The campaign I already discussed. The instant action mode was the place I spent most of my time, facing off against bots or friends. Lastly there's the galactic conquest mode. I really did appreciate this mode back in the day, but it has certainly aged. It is a lot of fun for the first time gamer as it makes a simplistic spin off of instant action mode and puts it in the context of conquering the galaxy. But after playing many other games and coming back, this mode just doesn't have the depth. I highly recommend downloading mods like the conversion pack to add even more variety in terms of maps, units, heroes, and vehicles. These breathed life into another play-through for me.Overall: I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of star wars and wants to experience large scale battles in a simply fun way. Do not expect a deep combat system or revolutionary campaign, just find some friends and load up instant action!

Posted: December 31, 2014
												READ THIS REVIEW IF HESITANT ON BUYING THIS GAME! I have been playing this game since it originally came out on ps2.I originally had this game on the PS2 (I still have it) and spent hundreds, if not thousands of hours on it. I got it 10 years ago the day it came out on PS2, now just got it on PC in the summer sale and still has to be the most fun and best game I ever played. I hope the new battlefront though is as good as this one, (2015) release date. The campaign is OK, not outstanding, but not bad. Though the campaign is roughly 6 hours long, Galactic Conquest is what most people will enjoy. This game is wonderful. The graphics are beautiful even to this day and the environments are very inspiring. Every Star Wars fan should check this one out. You can either do 1st or 3rd person shooting which is really nice and most shooter games don't give you that option, unfortunately. 3rd person is one its key characteristics and I hope Dice and EA implement it into the new game coming out along with the new movie. The difficulty of this game isn't really too bad at all, it only picks up in the last 3 or 4 missions. So frustrating, but again, it's amazing because I felt the struggles the Troopers felt going up against the rebel scum. It wasn't a walk in the park and the developers make you feel it. That's something I personally don't get from games like Halo or CoD. Though I have nothing against these games) If you are a fan of the way those shooters work, you will definitely enjoy this. Very well done and it's very compelling really. If you like Rogue Squadron, then you will like the way these ships fly, to say the least. This game is just a blast for any Star Wars fans, or FPS fans in general. It has a very nice story if you are a fan of Star Wars or just want to get deeper into the universe. I just really enjoy this game and truly can't find a downside unless a story line is a big deal to you. I was never really disappointed with this game, the Campaign was very enjoyable (and a bit challenging at times) but a little short and the maps are very fun to play on and has huge variety (From the snowy landscape of Hoth to the murky Swaps of Dagobah).This game is one of the best games I have ever played and the multiplayer is my favorite part which by the way is still there. I don't know why people are complaining about the online multiplayer, yes it was run by GAMESPY, and yes they did shutdown; but there is still DEDICATED SERVERS that you can go and play on if you want multiplayer action, and you can still HOST games and have friends join your server; you can also use Gameranger and join through there as well. The space combat is just how I remembered it fun and very unique in there being different ways to approach and destroy your opponent's ship. This game is a masterpiece of its time and deserves to be in your game library. (Hopefully with hours played on it :)I give it a 10/10 for being one of the best and really only good Star wars game out there.

Posted: October 8, 2014
												You may wonder to yourself, "Why should I buy a First Person Shooter that's this old?" Well, let me answer you with the reasons SWBFII tends to be the only FPS game I will play with my friends on a regular basis. Let me start with the single player. As much as FPS games are not the best for their story, SWBFII takes it away with the story of the 501st throughout the Star Wars universe with objectives that can tend to be more than just "Take this point" or "Kill this person" as you would see in any other FPS. From the tutorial until the last mission in game, the story objectives will either frustrate you (*Cough* Order 66 *cough*) or make you beg for more. Then there's galactic conquest, which is outside the campaign itself. This lets you control the republic, CIS, rebel alliance or empire and go through different planets, taking them over to fuel your empire while you research upgrades and troops to use. Next, the troops you choose. Every class has the same equivalent on the opposing team EXCEPT for the special troops (Dark Trooper, Clone Commander, Imp Officer, Wookiee, Bothan, Jet Trooper, Magnaguard and the rolling droids, don't remember what they're called). Each side has a heavy-weapons guy, a medic/engineer, a soldier and a sniper as well as two specials which I listed. Next, multiplayer, it's much more organized and less of a cluster than CoD. Melee is non-existent and it's rather equal in terms of game-play... not in terms of skill. The modes are much more organized between CTF-1 (one flag both sides fight to capture), CTF-2 (Classic Capture the Flag), Regular (until reinforcements run out), assault (First to get certain score wins) and so on. Next thing I like are the heroes, If you have them enabled in multiplayer, you can easily destroy a team... if not focused... which always happens. Otherwise, great first-person shooter. That if you choose can be third-person as well. A buy well worth the money.

Posted: January 16
												What Battlefront II (2005) had at or around launch:Campaign20+ Awesome MapsGraphics that made Battlefield 2 cry in defeat (for its time)Average AI (better than Battlefield 2's bots, I guess)Awesome Battlefield-based gameplayFull-fledged (and awesome) Space BattlesMOD SUPPORT!!!!A strong and thriving community (even a decade after it was released)No DLC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tGalactic ConquestWhat Battlefront (2015) had at or around launch:♥♥♥♥♥♥ "Campaign"♥♥♥♥♥♥ bot matchesLess than 18 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ maps (even with the content updates)Average-to-completely-crap DLC packsGraphics that made Black Ops III and Halo 5 cry in defeatNo Galactic Conquest :(A small and dying toxic communityFighter Squadron (EA's attempt to convince the masses that BFII's space battles don't exist).No mod support :(Gameplay that's worse than Homefront: RevolutionSo I guess what I'm trying to say is, I bought Battlefront EA because I was an idiot.Don't be an idiot. In fact, if you already bought Battlefront EA and you hate it, see if you can get a refund, and use the money to get this game. Because EA doesn't derserve your money after cheating you with the content-to-cost ratio. Think about how they unfairly charge you $120 for their window dressing of a game, and that this game is on Steam for a cheap $10. "OMFG, Tykylo!!!!!!!11!! U fokin wut m8? This trash heap lost itz multiplayer in 2014!!11!!! And it l00kz like vomitz today!!!1! No WAY dis iz better dan da musterpeece dat iz Battlefront by EA!!!11!!!1!" First of all, HOW DARE you call this game a trash heap. It may cower in fear in the face of better games like Black Ops III and Battlefield: Bad Company 2, but back in 2005, this game was the♥♥♥♥♥♥ And the graphics were high quality back in 2005. Multiplayer is still available through GameRanger, assuming you know how to Google. Also, may I remind you that multiplayer isn't everything? Campaign isn't all that stellar in this game, but it's certainly better than the "Training Mode" found in Battlefront EA. Not only that, this game came out with 24 maps AT LAUNCH, and brought with it full-on space combat, bot matches, and mod support, things we rarely see in modern gaming, "Da space battlez weer shet doe! All you did waz hold doun da fire button!" There was actually a lot more than that, buddy. In space battles, while they were point-based, involved a lot of tactics. If someone was leading a boarding party from a gunship, the people inside that tuna can in space had to make sure they didn't get blown up before they reached the hangar, and when they did get into the hangar, they had to take into account that other players are defending the ship's internals as well. If you were the leader, you truly felt like a badass. You could also take part in the dogfights around the ships, and try to blow up the ships that way. Bottom line; Battlefront II did (and still does) a great job at coercing players to work as a team without making it feel forced. "Yeah, but I paid lotz o monee for Battlefront EA. And you just hurt my pride, so ♥♥♥♥ off, newb!1!" Fair enough. Overall, this was, and still is, a great game. It gets a 9/10 from me.One gripe with it though; it's inaccurate.Stormtroopers couldn't aim for♥♥♥♥♥♥in the Death Star.Okay, now an actual review. Campaign You play as an anonymous 501st clone trooper, who has weathered every major Star Wars battle except Endor. And while clones do rapidly age, many clones were found alive after the Battle of Endor. We can guess that this clone died around 3 or 4 ABY, which would explain why the Battle of Endor was never featured in the campaign.The story isn't heavy like Call of Duty or Halo, but it provides an interesting perspective of the many Star Wars battles, and was more narrative-focused than its 2004 predecessor. It wasn't the stellar storytelling you'd expect from Crysis, but many people, like myself, enjoyed it regardless. It's neither terrible, nor stellar, but it's better than Battlefield 1's campaign (THAT overrated mess). Galactic Conquest Many people who helplessly defend EA's Battlefront, like the not-so-good and cringy-as-hell YouTuber BDobbinsFTW, start off by saying the Galactic Conquest modes in Battlefronts I and II were complete and utter trash. And apparently I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ idiot becuase I received nothing but death threats for saying I enjoyed the Galactic Conquest and that it actually was a good mode, but I wouldn't have it any other way. It plays a bit like RISK with some fun twists in it. It's certainly not the best mode, but it's enjoyable and playable. That mode was basically a teaser for Empire at War (which was an awesome game).  Graphics Many EA fanboys also attack this game's graphics without ever considering the fact that BFII was made in 2005. Yes, there were some amazing exceptions, like Halo 2, but I honestly found BFII's graphics better than it's competitor, Battlefield 2. And with the right tweaks (and mods), you can make it look absolutely stunning. Multiplayer Before I say anything else, two words: GameRanger and SWBFSpy.Many things about the multiplayer are just really good; the gameplay felt very smooth and fluid, Conquest mode was AMAZING (arguably better than Battlefield's Conquest mode), and the space maps were really well done. Keep in mind that all of that came from a mod group, Pandemic Studios.  Instant Action Basically offline multiplayer. The only problem you'll really run into are the mediocre bots. But hey, if you want worse AI, there's Battlefield and Halo. All in all, Star Wars: Battlefront II was, and still remains, one of the most highly cherished Star Wars games of all time. I'd highly recommend this to anyone who wants a good Star Wars shooter (an even better game than BFII goes by the name of Republic Commando). Make sure to get both this and the first Battlefront if you're interested; leave EA's Battlefront to rot.

Posted: November 17, 2015
Star Wars Battlefront II was a full scale galactic conflict that only a Jedi could master.It was also the first game I actually played online. It was the PS2 version, and I remember being blown away by what you could do in the game. Flying Tie fighters, riding a Tauntaun, delivery the force choke to lightsaber insta-kill with Darth Vader on Mos Eisley, and of course Hoth on conquest. If it was in the movies, you could do it in this game. What made this game so awesome was that every player could find a class, or role that worked for them. Everyone working towards the same goal of capturing the command posts. Support roles were important, not everyone had to be an all star FPS player to help the team. Well it's been 10 years, how has the game aged? Gamespy is no more, and playing online now requires VPN, or a third party solution for games over the internet. But this game still rocks the LAN party. The specs to run SWBF2 are so minimal it can run on almost any PC (not your grandmas Windows 95, but anything from 2010 and up should be fine). Its just as fun as it was back then, and even appeals to the younger audience as well. My son who is 7 will ask to play this more than any other game in our Steam library. The game also supports full controller. It's listed as partial controller support by Steam, but I was able to map all the functions I needed to play without using a keyboard or Xpadder. With the release of SWBF3 I have to admit I'm disappointed to hear the class system is gone, space battles are gone, the campaign is gone, and the only way to play with another human being is to use an EA server. So again did SWBF2 age well? The answer is yes, and one thing is certain. Long after EA kills the servers for SWBF3, you'll still find a dedicated group playing SWBF2  online.OLDER GAMER APPROVEDPOTATO PC CERTIFIED Visit our Currator Page

Posted: April 16, 2014
												Given the choice between a copy of Call of Duty Ghosts and 5 copies of this game, I'd pick 5 copies of this game. Really old game, one of the games I played on my original XBox and enjoyed for years (until Star Wars Battlefront I + II were both scratched into unusableness). They play well and give you the option of 3rd and 1st player. Playing Vanilla is fun, but nowhere near as much fun as with mods, particularly the Battlefront Extreme (pretty sure it's Extreme) mod which adds a ton of new maps, classes and vehicles for all factions. Setting up a private game is super easy, taking only a GameSpy account and a few minutes, and bam, you have a highly customizable private (or public) game with maps and classes from mods (or a vanilla game should you so desire). You can have an hour long fight, where you can fight over a thousand enemies (changable before you launch your singleplayer or multiplayer game), or a quick 4v4 skirmish with less than a hundred reinforcements for both sides. You can also have a dog fight in space, using a range of Interceptor class fighters to Dropships, you can knock out your advesary's vital ship components or land your boarding party in their hangar and wipe them out from the inside. Because it's such an old game, you shouldn't expect much in terms of visuals but for how old it is, it's pretty good. The low price is also awesome, being only at $10. It may just be the fond memories I have of this game and it's predecessor, but I'd give it a 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												This game may be 9 years old but is still worth picking up! As of July 2014 Multi-player was removed from this title but the singleplayer still provides hours of entertainment. What Battlefront 2 lacks behind in graphics it makes up with stunning gameplay. There is a variety of singleplayer gamemodes such as Instant Action, Campaign Mode and Galactic Conquest. Galactic Conquest is by far my favourite with it being much like a Star Wars edition of risk in where you command your space fleet across the galaxy defeating your opponent in both space battles and invading or defending a planet from a wave of attacks. However the campaign of this game is very short, easy and not the most entertaining with it only being about 2 hours long at most.One of the best features about game is the ability to control your factions heroes from Mace Windu to Han Solo to Darth Vader. You can help your teammates on the battlefield (Droids, Stormtroopers, Rebels etc.) defeat their enemy with the power of a lightsaber or a scoundrel like Han (Who shot first!) The only bad thing about this game is the lack of multiplayer, the graphics of this game are not the greatest but the game is still perfectly playable and will still provide hours of entertainment. In conclusion this game is worth the £6.99 (Time of Review Price) and any Star Wars fan should pick this game up!

												Part of me knows I should spend 2 hours thinking of and writing a full-length review for this game but honestly I don't think I really even need to say much. I've been playing Star Wars Battlefront II since I was just a little kid. I remember the first time I played the game, must've been back in '05 when it was freshly released. I was over at my aunts house and one of my cousins, Scott, took me too his room which was in the basement. We first spent about 2h on KOTOR I, and then moved onto BF2. If you don't have this game and can pick it up there's no excuse not to do so. 												Star Wars is one of my favorite movies ever. The first time I played Star Wars Battlefront II I was amazed by everything it has to offer. The game offers various maps based mosty off the prequel movies, but their are still a few sequel maps to play on. The game allows the player to switch between the Clone Wars and the Galactic Rebelion for every map. Every map comes with the gamemode "Conquest". Conquest is a game mode when both sides are fighting for command post to dominate the other side's  reinforcments. After the player has reached a certain amount of points, he or she can play was various characters in the movie like Obi-Wan and Darth Maul. Although, if you are playing with all NPC's the game is almost very easy and it won't take long before you reach a special character. Luckily Star Wars Battlefront II adds multiplayer and a ton of server to join. Sadly the community isn't as big as it might have used to be. You'll still be able to find a server with a good amount of people though. I have played this game a lot of times with my friends online and we all enjoyed the experience. Another cool thing about the game is that also include space combat when two sides try to take down the other's defences. The graphics are now lacking to today's standards but it's still fits the atmosphere of Star Wars. If you are a fan of Star Wars, this is a must have.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Nothing short of a fantastic improvement on the original. The addition of a proper story to the Single Player campaign is quite welcome, but also well thought out, and there are a few maps that you can only get to play by going through the single player. Space battles were added to the game, with air vehicles like xwings, etc being taken out of the land based levels as in the first one the levels just weren't quite big enough to allow for any strategic value to be gained by flying around. Unfortunately although it is a fun element, it quickly becomes repetitive and is probably the one glitchy point of the game, by glitchy I mean that its rather intermittent as to stationary turrets bothering to fire at you and next to impossible to dodge on some occasions, whereas other times you could shut your eyes and not get hit, even if you opened them and tried to fly into it. That aside it was still a step in the right direction. The other addition to the game is heroes characters ranging from Obi-Kenobi and Mace Windu, to Boba Fett and Han Solo, not to mention Yoda. The heroes are simple enough to use, but can easily turn the tide of battle, and in the hands of a master can mean total annihalation for a side. The only drawback to the heroes are that some seem to be a bit pathetic, but all in all its another step in the right direction for the Battlefront series. If you liked the first one, this is well worth the purchase. Ignore the bad reviews here people, if you like Star Wars this definately one of the good games in the franchise. Battlefield in the Star Wars Universe, who cares if its a ripoff, it makes for good gaming, not to mention the last good game in the battlefield series was the Desert Combat MOD for Battlefield 1942.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Battlefront II is an absolute essential for any Star Wars fan, and it's been regarded many times as the best third person shooter ever made.  It stands up tall alongside popular series like CoD and Battlefield, and provides a similar experience fine-tuned to anyone who loves glowstick swords and laser beam guns.  The atmosphere is great and nothing captures the feeling of playing a Jedi or a Stormtrooper on the battlefield better.  The vanilla game has plenty of content, but what really makes this title shine is the rich tapestry of mods and extra user-created maps that have been contributed over the past nine years.  That said, it's absolutely necessary to play the game with the Conversion Pack and Battlefront Extreme if you want the best experience possible.  There are also a bunch of great maps and mods to be found in the Community Hub here on Steam as well as on Filefront, so it's worth a look if you find something you like.Don't get too excited yet though, while it's a great game, I can tell you it hasn't aged amazingly.  The classes are noticeably unbalanced and there are glaring glitches present(one involving the infamous issue of the game crashing when Stereo Mix isn't enabled).  The servers aren't densely populated anymore and there are usually only one or two with around 40 players.  Despite minor problems and showing age, the game is still very much worth the $10, even if you only play quick matches on Instant Action.

I played this game so much the disk wore out, just like I did the first one, and if you liked that then this is a no brainer.  It works as it should for keyboard and mouse, but also supports controllers, but you'll need to program each and every class individually, long setup, but worth it, though you'll still have to use the mouse during class selection, and the keyboard to talk.  A third person shooter at heart, the first person was added exclusively for pc gaming at  one point, so if you're worried it hasn't aged well, don't.  Allthough it ain't the prettiest thing out there, it's still got a decent player base and most of the models and textures are more than tolerable.  First person isn't bad either, though it does look quite a bit more dated than the third person models, it gets the job done, and it's still better than system shock 2's original fps models, no worries there. Allthough there's a lot of complaints of allied and enemy A.I. you mostly won't notice it at all because you'll be dying and killing so much.  You'll have the odd glaringly bad A.I. every so often, but you won't mind it at all if you decide to hit the multiplayer servers!  If you like third person shooters, first person shooters, online multiplayer, varied maps, engaging (albiet repetitive in long doses),  and starwars, this game is for you.   In fact if any of those reasons by themselves should merit a purchase, especially at the low price of 5.00$ it winds up being during most sales, and with the NEW starwars battlefront coming later next year, you'll be wanting to hone your skills again.  So pick up your blaster, polish your best suit of white armor, and strap in, it's gonna be a fun ride through the past.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
-Quick Review-Star Wars Battlefront II was a first/third person shooter released to the PlayStation2, Xbox, and PC November 1, 2005 (Reference, Steam Store). The reason I state this is because "prepare yourself for PS2 and Xbox Generation Graphics.The game plays like a capture the flag, base control, skirmish first/third person shooter game. Recently multiplayer was lost because of GameSpy's shut down, however there are ways within the community to bring back the multiplayer features. (check out the forums, Steam or Reddit) -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  In the game you can play part of the story by playing Campaign Mode, "A shadow looms over the Republic. The Clone Wars have torn a rift across the Galaxy, its populace weak in allegiance and resolve." Basically you play the game as a member of the 501st Legion, Get used to hearing that, the clones will be sure to remind you every time you have a cut screen.You play from the Geonosis Attack, (seen in Star Wars episode 2), fight on Kashyyyk, Corescant Jedi Temple, Kamino, The Death Star Hoth, and a number of other locations seen in the Star Wars universe.(Having a star wars nerd moment, ignore if you don't care about the Expanded star wars universe)I do need to highlight a problem with the lore, the Clones received genetic alterations that made them age much faster than usual human beings, twice as fast to be precise. A clone surviving from the battle on Geonosis would most likely die of old age before ever reaching Hoth.Geonosis took place 22 BBY, Hoth 3 ABY, Most of the clones where in their 20's and 30's at the battle of Geonosis, so we're talking 60 to 70 year old cone troopers. But I digress, if you find this type of lore interesting I recommend checking out the Republic Commando books, I've read a great deal from them, I enjoy the Mandalorian back-story to the clone troopers.(End of Expanded Universe Rant)Game Play: The game controls like a standard first/third person shooter, the reason I refer to it as first/third is that you can change which mode you're playing with the options, I really liked playing in first person because the assault rifles would have scopes then. But to be honest third is probably a better way to play (you can see more).I've never played any other Battlefront games but I assume they all have very similar controls, in this one you can jump, roll, crouch, and sprint. Sprinting and rolling require stamina to use. Each class has its own different set of abilities, skills, and tactics.There are two categories: Land classes and space classes. You can have space battles in this game. I'll stick to the land classes to give an idea of the diversity in classes: Trooper, Heavy Weapons, Sniper, Engineer, Clone commander (special class 1), Jet trooper (special class 2). the special classes change based on which faction you're playing as, you can play as the Republic, CIS, Empire, or Rebel Alliance. There are also heroes in the game, so you can get in on some awesome lightsaber massacre action.In addition to classes, there are various game modes, you can play a command and conquer style game called "conquest" you can play through the campaign, you can simple play a sequence of matches against NPC's set to regular or elite difficulty (I generally just played offline matches against npc's). Achievements: There are no steam achievements for this game. Price: Star Wars Battlefront II $9.99, I recommend waiting for a sale, this is a very old game, and you can take your time on waiting for a great sale. I believe I purchased my copy at 75-90% off.The number of hours shown on steam is a little bit deceptive, I might only have 15 hours at this point, but I first played this game on the Playstation2, I loved it enough to buy it on steam, but it wouldn't load on my computer until I installed Windows7. So I've easily spent double that time or more.  Additionally I do intend to play it more, it's one of those games where it's nostalgic value to me is high. Conclusion: Remember this is an older game, wait for a sale, probably should be a star wars fan to enjoy it, multiplayer requires downloading third party software or you can just play against npc's. If you don't have a problem with anything I've listed, suit up trooper, the Battle awaits you! I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Get ready for nostalgia, and a lot of it.I first played this game as a kid at a couple different friend's houses and fell in love with the game.STORYLINEYou are a member of the 501st at the Battle of Geinosis. From there you are given different missions that start in the Clone Wars. Order 66 is given and you witness the fall of the Republic and the rise of the Empire and then the fall of the Empire. all of this while still a member of the 501st. The missions are straight forward and objectives are given one right after the other. Some are easier than others but over all, not bad. The only thing I would have changed is some of the space missions, but space missions are optional. Overall 9/10GRAPHICS AND THINGS OF THE LIKENESSGameplay is pretty smooth. I personally never had any issues, but that may be because of my pc. My pc isn't the best but it runs pretty good for me. No lag, fast loading. I have no complaints. Graphics wise, it's not that bad for a 10 year old game. It has that old game feel that makes you nostalgic. A somewhat blocky appearence to the maps but thats to be expected. The characters look very smooth for their time, not extremely blocky but not completely smooth, but like I said; Smooth for their time. Overall 9/10REPLAY VALUEThere are a few different game modes that I'm going to mention. First, and my personal favorite, Galactic Conquest. This is a turn based mode. You can play as any of the sides in the Clone Wars and the Galactic Civil War. You take turns moving your fleet across a small galaxy, conquering the galaxy. You win when you have control of all star systems and elliminated all enemy fleets. This mode can be played 4 times before you start repeating. It's completely random which adds more to the fun. the only thing I don't like about this mode is the number of troops that you have in a fleet. 150 points to win on land and you need to score 180 points in space. The number of points you get for completeing "objectives" is a lot for the win point to be 150 or 180. So for that I give 7/10. The other mode is Instant Action. Pretty straight forward. you can make your own map list and when you hit launch, it goes through all the maps in your list. It also allows you to edit some settings like the number of points you need to win, number of troops on land battles, how often special characters show up, and more. This is where I have the most fun because I can make a map list that will be exactly how I want it. Only complaint is you can't play both Clone Wars and Galactic Civil War on all maps. Some maps are exclusive to one era. for that 8/10. Overall for replay value I would give 8/10

 Episode IV: A New Hope It is a period of civil war. Rebel spaceships, striking from a hidden base, have won their first victory against the evil Galactic Empire. During the battle, Rebel spies managed to steal secret plans to the Empire’s ultimate weapon, the DEATH STAR, an armored space station with enough power to destroy an entire planet. Pursued by the Empire’s sinister agents, Princess Leia races home aboard her starship, custodian of the stolen plans that can save her people and restore freedom to the galaxy…. Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back It is a dark time for the Rebellion. Although the Death Star has been destroyed, Imperial troops have driven the Rebel forces from their hidden base and pursued them across the galaxy.Evading the dreaded Imperial Starfleet, a group of freedom fighters led by Luke Skywalker has established a new secret base on the remote ice world of Hoth.The evil lord Darth Vader, obsessed with finding young Skywalker, has dispatched thousands of remote probes into the far reaches of space… Episode VI: The Return of the Jedi Luke Skywalker has returned to his home planet of Tatooine in an attempt to rescue his friend Han Solo from the clutches of the vile gangster Jabba the Hutt.  Little does Luke know that the GALACTIC EMPIRE has secretly begun construction on a new armored space station even more powerful than the first dreaded Death Star.When completed, this ultimate weapon will spell certain doom for the small band of rebels struggling to restore freedom to the galaxy... Episode 1: The Phantom Menace Turmoil has engulfed the Galactic Republic. The taxation of trade routes to outlying star systems is in dispute.Hoping to resolve the matter with a blockade of deadly battleships, the greedy Trade Federation has stopped all shipping to the small planet of Naboo.While the congress of the Republic endlessly debates this alarming chain of events, the Supreme Chancellor has secretly dispatched two Jedi Knights, the guardians of peace and justice in the galaxy, to settle the conflict.... Episode II: Attack of the Clones There is unrest in the Galactic Senate. Several thousand solar systems have declared their intentions to leave the Republic. This separatist movement, under the leadership of the mysterious Count Dooku, has made it difficult for the limited number of Jedi Knights to maintain peace and order in the galaxy. Senator Amidala, the former Queen of Naboo, is returning to the Galactic Senate to vote on the critical issue of creating an ARMY OF THE REPUBLIC to assist the overwhelmed Jedi.... Episode III: Revenge of the Sith War! The Republic is crumbling under attacks by the ruthless Sith Lord, Count Dooku. There are heroes on both sides. Evil is everywhere. In a stunning move, the fiendish droid leader, General Grievous, has swept into the Republic capital and kidnapped Chancellor Palpatine, leader of the Galactic Senate. As the Separatist Droid Army attempts to flee the besieged capital with their valuable hostage, two Jedi Knights lead a desperate mission to rescue the captive Chancellor.... The Force Awakens Luke Skywalker has vanished. In his absence, the sinister FIRST ORDER has risen from the ashes of the Empire and will not rest until Skywalker, the last Jedi, has been destroyed.With the support of the REPUBLIC, General Leia Organa leads a brave RESISTANCE. She is desperate to find her brother Luke and gain his help in restoring peace and justice to the galaxy.Leia has sent her most daring pilot on a secret mission to Jakku, where an old ally has discovered a clue to Luke’s whereabouts . . . .

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												10/10This is the epitome of Star Wars inside a video game. Battlefront II builds upon the already successful and fun capture-the-point aspect of battlefront I but adds an element of chaos with the addition of new vehicles, soldier type, and Jedi. The standard team versus team battles are fun and engaging. It is perfectly timed to let you have fun and explore new ways of winning but does not make the game feel tedious. Jedi versus Jedi mode offers new fun to the classic capture-the-point game type. The extra speed and abilities of Jedi's makes this game mode fast pace and exciting. With the ability to sprint at super speed, jump to higher length, and duel other players, Jedi versus Jedi mode is one of the most addicting and fun game types there is. Not to mention the space battles, which are very well done. The games offers enough control to the player where one needs to slow down, aim, and shoot to destroy the opponent's battle cruiser but leaves enough freedom where the players can achieve victory through different means. Overall, this game is a classic of the PS2 era and I would recommend everyone who likes a casual, action packed game. May the force be with you

												What can I say about Battlefront? This game was a part of my childhood, and even if it wasn't, even if i wasn't a huge Star Wars nerd, I'd still love this classic game.It comes with memorable maps, great gamemodes, and a very enjoyable game overall.If any of you are Star Wars fans, or even just fans of the class based shooter, this game is a must have.UPDATE: I've got a LOT more to say about this game.The game types are absolutely fantastic. They have Multiplayer, which is self explanatory, yet still awesome. They have Galactic Conquest, a single-player conquest game in which you try to conquer star systems on memorable planets such as Kamino and Kashyyyk.The maps are memorable and immersive as hell. Especially the space maps. They have many different maps such as Geonosis, Mustufar, Mygeeto, Yavin 4, and even the Death Star and Mos Eisely, Tatooine.My god, I'd like to say more about this amazing game, but it's almost midnight where I am and I'm tired.I absolutely love this game and if you decide to buy it (WHICH YOU SHOULD), I hope you love it too!

												Pros:- Good-looking- Tight controls- Optional 1st or 3rd person view- Very fun game play- Original Star Wars soundtrack- Epic fights on huge fronts- Galactic Conquest- Instant action playlistsCons:- No multiplayer support* (uses gamespy)- Campaign lacks replayability- No steam achievements*There are 3rd-party applications which can allow multiplayer. I personally use GameRanger, which works great.SummaryThis game is a marvelous experience. The battles are massive, so you never feel like you're carrying your team when you put effort into a battle. Strategy and non-strategy are both viable ways of winning a game. It is unfortunate that it uses gamespy, however, because the game is no longer supported since it shut down. Achievements would provide some much-needed replay ability. Overall, though, one of the best games in my library by a long shot.

												There's often an issue with games I liked as a little kid, such as Sonic Heroes and Nicktoons Unite, being either bad or just plain meh. Star Wars Battlefront II is a game I loved as a little kid, and I was skeptical as to if I would still like it. Well, this game is still just as amazing as I remember. content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Nostalgic is the feeling that you should get when playing this fantastic game. This is the squeal to the famed and fantastic game, Star Wars Battlefront (1). The campaign takes place in the mid-late Clone Wars era. You play as a battle-hardened soldier from the 501st legion (aka Vader's Fist) lead by Jedi Knight/General Anakin Skywalker. The campaign takes you through multiple planets and systems such as: Mygeeto, Kashyyyk,  Felucia, Utapau, Kamino, Hoth, The Death Star and many other planets/battle grounds. Not only can you play as Clone Troopers, Droids, Rebels and Storm Troopers, but you can also play as many different Jedi and Sith. Gameplay wise, you are able to play as 6 Different Classes. These include: Normal Infantry, Heavy, Scout, Engineer, Special class 1, Special class 2 and Jedi/Sith (You will need to unlock these characters through points earned during the battle). Did I mention you can also use and command a variety of different vehicles? From small AT-RT's to Gigantic AT-AT's, these are only some of the MANY different vehicles that are able to be used. Having multiple tanks on your side can mean a swift victory for you and your team. But what if you are going against them? Well, mines and rockets are always available for your use in demolitions. In this Battlefront, you are also able to participate in space battles. They too, are fantastic and fun to play. Multiplayer wise, the Game Spy severs for this game have been shut down. Although, don't give up your hope. Third Party hosts such as Game Ranger allow you to host and join servers set up by other people. This can still supply you and your friends with the nostalgia received from this amazing game. Here is the Game Ranger site: http://www.gameranger.comEven the best games have a few little flaws here and there. A few things I think that should've been included in this game  can include more squad commands. In the previous Battlefront, there were 4 commands. They include; 'Follow Me', 'Move out', 'Hold Position' and 'At Ease'. These squad commands can prove to be extremely helpful for strategically capturing command posts and ultimately, winning battles. It also would've been good if they added commands for star fighters. For example, if you pressed the 'Follow Me' key, the fighter you were looking at would start following you and so on.  All in all, this game is very fun, balanced and extremely enjoyable for both Star Wars and Non-Star Wars fans alike. I can't wait for the next Battlefront game. If you do at any time, get bored of the same maps, you can always download mods from the Battlefront community. They can supply you and your friends with an endless amount of fun! I'll give this game a 10/10, it's absolutely fabulous! If you are a Star Wars fan and haven't got it yet, buy it immediately!

Positives:This and Battlefront 1 are two of the main reasons I still own my original Xbox.The ground battles are amazingly easy to learn and play as well as ridiculously fun to get killing spreas on, they feel more like actual battles then any other game I've played (including the Battlefield series). The space battles are fun but hard as well just being beautiful even with out dated graphics and they feel like a genuine space simulator and not a stupid rail shooter. Last but not least; the Jedi battles. Never in my life have I had this much fun with a lightsaber; not as a kid with toy, not as a teen with other Star Wars games and not with any other sword battle game; EVER! Whether you're in a normal ground battle literally ripping though squad after squad of droids or in the Heroes Vs Villians mode on Mos Eisley. It is in everyway the just stupid, dumb, amazing fun!Negatives:There are only a couple reasons why this game is not as amazing (and perfect) as it's predicessor; one is the squad commands being missing for no reason and the other is the maps are not nearly as good as the original.Final verdict:9.5/10 Amazing game, why have you not bought it yet?

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												So, Star Wars: Battlefront II is now a decade old.  Is it worth $10?  Yeah, I'd say so.  The graphics look good for 10 years ago.  The gameplay itself is fairly arcadey and simplistic (there are no unlocks, really), but the maps are fun to play.  On the whole, I find it to be an enjoyable casual shooter for offline play, particularly in the Galactic Conquest mode.  Also of note, here are things this ten-year-old version of Battlefront has that the new EA/DICE version does not:- A $10 price tag (less if you get it on sale).- An actual space mode, which also lets you attempt to board and sabotage the enemy capital ship.- Vehicles that let more than one player ride in them.- Spawn points that you can select, instead of randomly appearing on the battlefield.- More maps per game mode.- Clone Wars Era troopers and maps.- Soldier classes with different specific abilities.- Single-player offline mode against (admittedly rather dim) bots, where you can play pretty much the full version of the game.- A dedicated single-player campaign (although, really, it's just the same maps from multiplayer, with you playing as a member of the 501st with the odd cutscene here and there).So, yeah, I'd say this is well worth your money if you just want a casual shoot-em-up to screw around with here and there.  Is it an amazing game to stand the test of time and be lauded for generations to come?  Nah, not really.  It's fun, but it's simple.  On the other hand, that's kind of the appeal.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
STAR WARS™ Battlefront™ II is an intense first- and third-person shooter, developed by Pandemic Studios and released in 2005. A highly successful title due to a more narrative-focused approach, the ability to take part in battles on some of the films' most iconic locations has secured it's popularity and replay value since release, with a passionate modding community to boot.Providing much-needed wish fulfilment and satisfaction for both Star Wars fans and gamers alike, the variety on offer here is substantial. The campaign itself takes place over both of the default eras, in which you assume the role of one of the class-types of the legendary 501st during the rise of the Empire. Most missions involve a set of objectives that introduce the player to the other game modes provided, such as Conquest, CTF, Assault or Hunt. Most of these modes are a standard affair for the shooter genre but space battles are also available. There's a fairly standard roster and loadout options at first, as well as the ability to unlock two higher tier classes upon exceeding a predetermined amount of points. However, the most fascinating addition to the series is the ability to unlock characters - both friend and foe - from the films and duel it out with your favourite heroes. The lightsaber gameplay is among the best the Star Wars IP is yet to see; Pandemic have absolutely nailed the feel of the various strengths and styles of the characters on offer. Though the game features some surprisingly complex A.I. enemies and teammates, it is admittedly prone to frustrating and occasionally amusing quirks. The level of difficulty and challenge is also minimal once you get the hang of it. Outside of the campaign, the options for Instant Action and Galactic Conquest will undoubtedly please many with the ability to setup custom battles and campaigns but the true values comes from the tonne of mods available. Since the death of the Gamespy servers, unofficial clients have assumed control of the community's ongoing interest but playing on your own is just as good as it is with others. From Conquest matches that run down to the wire to extremely intense shootouts down tightly-packed corridors; one-on-one duels with lightsabers to sprawling dogfights in space, this is one of the best shooters to appear in recent years and a perfect example of both a Star Wars game and a shooter done right. Pros Near perfect lightsaber combat. Impressive visuals with often stunning lighting and effects. Top-notch shooting mechanics that rival even more recent iterations and spiritual successors. John Williams' score and the classic sound design. Superb modding community and replay value. Controller support. Great offline/bot gameplay.Cons Partially dead and elitist multiplayer/clan community. Difficulty is essentially negated after a while. Clunky vehicle controls and navigation. No Steam achievements or trading cards, if you're into that sort of thing.Final Thoughts: Whether or not you're a fan of the Star Wars universe, Battlefront™ II has what much of the shooter genre has forgotten and all the makings of a good time. Intense and extremely enjoyable sci-fi action, fans will be right at home here, as will newcomers. It is not perfect, but well worth a look.Rating: 9/10

Posted: November 15, 2014
												Since the new Battlefront game came out a month ago, I felt like it was absolutely necessary to rework my review. I've been playing this game since I first got my PS2, and for Nostalgia's sake, I bought it again for the PC. I must say that I didn't regret buying it again for another system because I feel like the price was worth it when I first bought it(Around 5 bucks like 2 years ago). Even though it's 10 years old now, the game still holds up as possibly one of the best Star Wars games to have ever been made. It has a variety of locations for maps, and allowed for single player action which spanned out into either Galactic Conquest, Campaign Mode, and Instant Action. While the graphics are certainly dated, the game is so much fun to play through due to how you were really thrust into the Star Wars Universe and felt like you were just an average soldier on some sort of galactic battlefield. Another thing this game has going for it are the mods and community created maps. While Filefront is down, you can still find a large amount of maps made by the community and mods that vastly improve the game and make it look much better than it originally was. While I would say that the game survived so long was due to nostalgia, I'd have to say it's because of the mods. The amount of side mods(Republic v. CIS, Empire v. Rebels, etc.) and interesting maps made by the modding and mapping community just give you an infinite amount of possibilities with what you can do in Star Wars Battlefront II. I don't think any Star Wars game has had the virtue of having so many community made things for it to explore and try out like SWBII. Along with that, the fun gameplay, and nostalgia, this game is definitely worth the buy.

Posted: May 8, 2013
												If you're reading this, I have one question to ask you.Why don't you have this game?Seriously, this game is just simply worth owning because its so much fun. It features a great offline mode, a varity of options and a very chaotic multiplayer. Not only that, but this game has a great modding community. You can see things from maps and units to entire game patches. However, the game does have some major compatibility issues with Windows Vista and up. First off, the main menu is permanently stuck at a fixed resolution(you can change it from the launch options, but the entire menu will become messed up), however 1980 X 1080 is supported when in game. Second off, there's an audio bug that halts the audio for a few seconds, then continues on. That can be fixed via launch options and by enabling stereo mix in your sound settings. Now the next big thing I havn't gotten, but other have been having crashing problems. From what I heard, you can prevent it from happening if you have something plugged into your mic jack (weird solution, I know). Aside from these issues, the game shines great and is amazing fun. If you like large open battles, epic space battles with starships, and intense close quaters combat, this game is for you.
